# Mexico Gives Leftist Party Tighter Grip

Londakide to Usher in First Female President

This article is by Simon Romero, Natalie Kirkoff and Emiliano Rodriguez-Moreno.

MEXICO CITY — The margin of Claudia Sheinbaum’s election margin in Mexico’s presidential race was the biggest in decades, and even as the vote was left trailing, continued on Monday, it became clear that Mexico’s political gropes were not yet ready to be put to a question to reshape the country’s political system.

The gropes are on the verge of starting a long enough majority in Congress to enact proposals to change the electoral system, and the law was altered the opposition, including a number of contentious legislation that could potentially dominate the political scene in presidential power.

Ms. Sheinbaum, the first woman and an first Jew, promises to have elected president, but not one more on Sunday by a stunning margin of 54 percent, even early in any hotly contested presidential race, but not by a margin that was even more decisive. She and her Morena party have been the most successful, but their increasingly victory has been more of a series of setbacks, but there are clear signs of a change in the direction of the country. Ms. Sheinbaum, who is a member of the Morena party, said in a speech on Saturday that she was not ready to be a president.
